item.title: Melinda add a quote by Richard Yates
item.description: "I'm only interested in stories that are about the crushing of the human heart." -- Richard Yates

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Martin Luther King Jr.
item.description: "Our lives begin to end the day we become silent about things that matter." -- Martin Luther King Jr.

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Carson McCullers
item.description: "I think we look for the differences in people because it makes us less lonely." -- Carson McCullers

item.title: Melinda add a quote by William Carlos Williams
item.description: "In summer, the song sings itself." -- William Carlos Williams

item.title: Melinda add a quote by cl
item.description: "failure is the compost from which we grow success. " -- cl

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Indian saying
item.description: "The head understands, the heart cannot speak -follow the river." -- Indian saying

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Chogyam Trungpa
item.description: "We must begin our practice by walking the narrow path of simplicity, the hinayana path, before we can walk upon the open highway of compassionate action, the mahayana path." -- Chogyam Trungpa

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Mae West
item.description: "You only live once, but if you do it right, once is enough." -- Mae West

item.title: Melinda add a quote by E.E. Cummings
item.description: "It takes courage to grow up and become who you really are." -- E.E. Cummings

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Anais Nin
item.description: "We write to taste life twice, in the moment and in retrospect." -- Anais Nin

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Mahatma Gandhi
item.description: "Be the change that you wish to see in the world." -- Mahatma Gandhi

item.title: Melinda add a quote by Charles Baudelaire
item.description:
"Be Drunken, Always. That is the point; nothing else matters. If you would not feel the horrible burden of Time weigh you down and crush you to the earth, be drunken continually.
Drunken with what? With wine, with poetry or with virtue, as you please. But be drunken.
And if sometimes, on the steps of a palace, or on the green grass in a ditch, or in the dreary solitude of your own room, you should awaken and find the drunkenness half or entirely gone, ask of the wind, of the wave, of the star, of the bird, of the clock, of all that flies, of all that speaks, ask what hour it is; and wind, wave, star, bird, or clock will answer you: "It is the hour to be drunken! Be Drunken, if you would not be the martyred slaves of Time; be drunken continually! With wine, with poetry or with virtue, as you please." -- Charles Baudelaire
